717093f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717093f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Fulton Street, showing prominently the Singer
and the Equitable Buildings on opposite sides of this thoroughfare.
The edifice shown on the right is the 26-story American Telephone and
Telegraph Co. Building, No. 207-195 Broadway, and ocoupying the block
front from Fulton to Dey Streets.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717113f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717113f-a.text:
Broadway, (center, main entrance thereon) west side, between Fulton
(right) and Vesey (left) Streets, showing St. Pauls Chapel with its
surrounding Grave Yard that extends to Church Street (right foreground);
this view being eastward from the latter point. Buildings across the
background are on the east side of Broadway between Ann (left) and
Fulton Streets, prominent of which is the 25-story St. Paul Building.
No. 220-222 Broadway.
June 4, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same from a slightly different angle. The twin towered structure]
shown on the left is the 32-story Park Row Building. No. 13-21
Park Row.

717106f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717106f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Fulton Street.
St. Pauls' P.E. Chapel is on the left and occupies
the frontage from Fulton to Vesey Street's. Under
demolition in the next block is half of the old Astor
House. This is to be improved with a 7-story structure.
Subsequently the remainder will be rased for the site
of the 44-story Transportation Building. The magnificent
55-storied Woolworth Building is just north of the
latter location. The pyramidal topped strncture beyond
is the Postal Telegraph and Cable Building.
1913-4
Thru New York Historical Society
MAY BE RE'iOTUCED

719963f-a.title: Manhattan: Fulton Street - Broadway
719963f-a.text:
Fulton Street, north side, west from but not including Broadway, to
and including Church Street. The view shows the rear of the Vestry
Office of Trinity Church, fronting on CEurch Street, and at the western
extremity of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel' Cemetery.
May 19, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717096f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717096f-a.text:
Broadway,West Side,shouing the Fulton Street Bridge
and St.Paul's Chapel.P.E.Church.
IEG7
Lnderhill,Photographor,
18 Park Place,
New York.
No Reproductions.

717098f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717098f.text:
Broadway, between Veseg and Fulton Street, from the
Church yard of Saint Pauls, before many old trees were
cht down.
E.L.Senry
MiY PE REPRODUED  1870.

717099f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717099f-a.text:
Broadway, north from and including Fulton Street, showing possibly
a curb trading group at the S.E. corner of same. On the left appears
St. Pauls P.E. Chapel, the Astor House, The Postal Telegraph and Cable
Building and the turret of the Home Life Insurance Co. Building. On
the opposite side one sees a portion of City Hall Park and the United
States Post Office; the latter obscured by the columns of the National
Park Bank Building. Under ground, at this point the I.R.T. Subway is
under construction.
August 25, 1903.
Cormdoiidated Edieon Co.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
NRcq wt 99t;

719961f-b.title: Manhattan: Fulton Street - Broadway
719961f-b.text:
(1)
Fulton Street, north side, east from and including Broadway, to, but
not including NasSau Street. Rlso shown is Broadway, at, adjoining and
north of the N.E. corner of Fulton Stret. St. Paul's Protestant Episco-
pal Church is on the extreme left.
About 1904.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPR.ODUCTIO.IS.
(2)
A portion of the same in a westward direction and showing the Chapel
and Grounds with the Trinity Vestry Buildings at their rear (Church
Street). On the right appears a portion of the Enox Building, later called
the United Building, which bears Nos. 212 Broadway and 165 Fulton Street.
June 3, 1904.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717109f-c.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717109f-c.text:
Broadway, west side, between Fulton (left) and Vesey (center) Streets
as seen southwestward on Park Row, and showing St. Pauls P.E. Chapel and
grounds occupying that block,west to Church Street. Partially shown on
the right is the Astor Building, at the N.W . corner of Broadway and
Vesey Street. This is a set of 3 views, No. 1 and 2 being in the same
direction while No. 3 is viewed eastward on Vesey Street (church yards
northern boundary) from Church Street to Broadway. Nos. 2 and 3 show
the Chapel and spire under renovations.
October 1925.
Views 2 \& 3:eJuly 17, 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

717123f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717123f-a.text:
212, 214 and 218 Broadway, at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner
of Fulton Street (right) showing the Knox (later,,the United) Building and
the National Park Bank. On the left appears a portion of the United
States Post Office, of which, the Park Row side is seen. The building
bearing the advertising sign, No. 218 was the site of Barnums Museum and
is today (1937) a part of the 25-story St. Paul Building site; the other
structures remaining the same.
1898.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717115f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717115f-b.text:
Broadway, west side, from Fulton to Vesey Streets. The above
is the location of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel and
where ahi unknown (to the writer) function is taking place. The
floner strewn table is at the rear of the church and to the foot of
the tablet commemorating the bravery of General Richard Montgomery.
Fulton Street is on the left. View No. 2 is in the opposite direction
and silhouettes the reverend bagpiper against the Astor Building.
About 1932
Views 1 and 2
MAY BE REPRODUCED

717108f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717108f-b.text:
St. Pauls P.E. Chapel, Broadway.west side, between Fulton and Vesey
Streets. A set of 3 views eastward on Fulton Street, showing the Chapel
and grounds as seen from the rear. The 7-story white structure appearing
on the left is the Astor Building, at the N.W . corner of Broadway and
Vesey Street. Those on the right are Nos. 212, 6-story United Building,
at the N.E. corner of Fulton Street and Broadway; No. 214, 7-story National
Park Bank and No. 220-222, the 25-story St. Paul Building. All of the
latter are on the east side of Broadway, north from Fulton to Ann Streets.
May 1923.
View No. 2:-May 1925.
View No. 3:eJuly 1928.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(4)
The same as seen eastward on Vesey Street; the north side of the
dhurch Yard. On the right appears a portion of the American Telephone
and Telegraph Co. Building, at the S.W. corner of Broadway and Fulton
Street.
May 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

717091f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717091f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Fulton Street, showing prominently the Singer
and the Ecuitable Buildings on opposite sides of this thoroughfare.
The edifice shown on the right is the 26-story American Telephone and
Telegraph Co. Building, No. 207-195 Broadway, and occupying the block
front from Fulton to Dey Streets.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717100f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717100f.text:
Broadway and Fulton Street.
St. Paul's Church.
n.d.

719962f-a.title: Manhattan: Fulton Street - Broadway
719962f-a.text:
Bulton Street, north side, west from but not including Broadway, to
and including Church Street. The view shows a portion of St. Paul's
Protestant Episcopal Chapel and grounds, the Sixth Ave., Elevated on
Church Street, and the New York Telephone Building (West Street), are in
the background.
June 4, 1933.
P. L Sper.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717116f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Fulton Street
717116f.text:
Broadway, west side, between Fulton and Vesey Streets, showing a view
of stones inside of St. Pauls Churchyard. This, a set of 3 views shows
in No. 1, the Rhinelander plot; No. 2, the tombstones of Captain James
Lawrence; No. 3 the ''United'' graves.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.
